Title: How Nature Affects Cooperation in Common Pool Resource Systems

This proposal seeks to investigate the critical role of nature in shaping human behavior and cooperation in the management of common pool resources. Despite the importance of these resources, their sustainable use is often hindered by collective action problems and social dilemmas. We propose to examine how the natural environment influences the preferences and incentives of economic agents, ultimately affecting the management of renewable resources.

Our research will focus on three key mechanisms: (1) tipping points and thresholds in natural systems that may encourage cooperation, (2) the impact of resource abundance volatility on risk preferences and community-based management, and (3) the interaction between leadership and the natural environment in promoting cooperation. By exploring these mechanisms, we aim to identify the circumstances under which natural preconditions and social settings promote the sustainable use of renewable resources.

Our approach will be interdisciplinary, combining theoretical and statistical methods from economics and sustainability science. We will conduct our research across three continents, ensuring the results are generalizable and applicable to diverse contexts. The ultimate goal of this project is to provide evidence-based insights for policymakers and practitioners seeking to design effective strategies for the sustainable management of common pool resources. By elucidating the complex relationships between nature, human behavior, and cooperation, this project will contribute to a deeper understanding of how to promote environmental sustainability and social welfare.
